Last accessed: 9 August 2009.</ref> While not formally established as an organization until 1974 in the wake of the [[Yom Kippur War]], Gush Emunim sprang out of the conquests of the [[Six-Day War]] in 1967, encouraging [[Israeli settlement|Jewish settlement]] of the land based on the belief that, according to the [[Torah]], [[God]] gave it to the [[Jewish people]].<ref>Analyses of Gush Emunim have been carried out by [[David Newman (geographer)|David Newman]]. See: D. Newman, `Gush Emunim', ''Encyclopaedia Judaica Decennial Yearbook'', 1994, pp. 171-172. Keter Publishers; D. Newman, `Gush Emunim: Between Fundamentalism and Pragmatism', ''Jerusalem Quarterly'', 39, 33-43, 1986: D. Newman, `From âhitnachalutâ to âhitnatkutâ: The Impact of Gush Emunim and the Settlement Movement on Israeli Societyâ, ''Israel Studies'', Vol 10 (3, 2005: See also T. Hermann & D Newman, `Extra Parliamentarism in Israel: A Comparative Study of Peace Now and Gush Emunim', ''Middle Eastern Studies'', 28 (3), 509-530, 1992. </ref> While Gush Emunim no longer exists officially, vestiges of its power remain in Israeli society.<ref>[http://www.sais-jhu.edu/bin/q/t/ReligiousZionismAllen.pdf The Ideological Resonance of Zionist Fundamentalism in Israeli Society], Katherine Allen, Behavioral Sociology of Identity Conflict, Spring 2005</ref><ref>Encyclopaedia Judaica: Volume 8, p. 145</ref>
==Political affiliations== Gush Emunim was closely associated with, and highly influential in, the [[National Religious Party]] (NRP). Nowadays they refer to themselves âand are referred to by the [[Israeli media]] asâ '''Ne'emanei Eretz Yisrael''' × ××× × ××¨×¥ ××©×¨×× (Hebrew: "Those who are loyal/faithful to the [[Land of Israel]]").
== History == Gush Emunim was founded by students of Rabbi [[Zvi Yehuda Kook|Tzvi Yehuda Kook]] in February 1974 in the living room of [[Haim Drukman]]<ref>[[Ian Lustick]], ''For the land and the Lord: Jewish fundamentalism in Israel,'' Council on Foreign Relations, 1988 p.63.</ref><ref>[[Gershom Gorenberg]], ''The Accidental Empire: Israel and the Birth of the Settlements, 1967-1977,'' Times Books, Henry Holt & Co., 2006 p.356.</ref>, who is also credited with coining the term.<ref>Gorenberg, ''The Accidental Empire,'' p.356.</ref> In addition to Drukman, its ideological and political core consisted of other disciples such as [[Hanan Porat]], [[Moshe Levinger]], [[Shlomo Aviner]], Eleazar Waldman, Yoel Ben-Nun and Yaacov Ariel.<ref>Lustick, ''For the land and the Lord,' p.73.</ref> Kook remained its leader until his death in 1982.
In late 1974, an affiliated group named ''Garin Elon Moreh'', led by Rabbi [[Menachem Felix]] and [[Benjamin (Beni) Katzover]], attempted to establish a settlement on the ruins of the [[Sebastia (town)|Sebastia]] train station dating from the [[Ottoman Empire|Ottoman]] period. After seven attempts and six removals from the site by the [[Israel Defense Forces]], an agreement was reached according to which the [[Israeli government]] allowed 25 families to settle in the [[Kadum]] army camp southwest of [[Nablus]]/[[Shechem]]. The [[Sebastia]] agreement was a turning point that opened up the southern [[West Bank]] to Jewish settlement. The small mobile home site housing 25 families eventually became the municipality of [[Kedumim]], one of the major settlements in the West Bank. The Sebastia model was subsequently copied in [[Beit El]], [[Shavei Shomron]], and other settlements.
== Ideology == Gush Emunim's beliefs were based heavily on the teachings of Rabbi [[Abraham Isaac Kook]] and his son, Rabbi [[Zvi Yehuda Kook|Tzvi Yehuda Kook]], who taught that [[secular]] [[Zionist]]s, through their conquests of ''[[Land of Israel|Eretz Israel]]'', had unwittingly brought about the beginning of the Messianic age, which would culminate in the coming of the [[Moshiach|messiah]], which Gush Emunim supporters believe can be hastened through Jewish settlement on land they believe God has allotted to the Jewish people as set forth in the [[Tanakh|Hebrew Bible]]. The organisation supported attempts to coexist with the Arab population, rejecting the [[population transfer]]s proposed by [[Meir Kahane]] and his followers.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.knesset.gov.il/lexicon/eng/gush_em_eng.htm|title=Gush Emunim|work=Lexicon|publisher=Knesset|year=2008}}</ref>
In the wake of the mass [[eviction]] of Jews from [[Gaza]] by the Israeli government[http://www.nytimes.com/2005/06/30/international/middleeast/30cnd-mideast.html?ex=1120795200&en=150daf33c7731d94&ei=5070&emc=eta1], the violent eviction of Jews from [[Amonah]], and numerous other similar events on a smaller scale in more recent years, many members of the GE community have been having second thoughts about this [[ideology]]. For a fuller discussion of this recent issue, see [[Hardal#Ideological Crisis and Political Schism|Hardal]].
